thread.title: Bonds: Traders flock to the haven of public debt
thread.title_full: Bonds: Traders flock to the haven of public debt

title: Bonds: Traders flock to the haven of public debt
text:
Print 
LONDON (ShareCast) - A wave of selling hit all asset classes late on Tuesday as investors reacted to the impasse in Greece and growing worries over recent events in China's stock markets. Against that backdrop, in its annual so-called article IV consultation with the United States the International Monetary Fund called on the US Federal Reserve to hold off on raising interest rates until the first half of 2016. 
As of 16:25 the Dax-30 was down by 1.69% to stand at 10,706.93, followed by a 1.6% fall in Madrid's Ibex 35 to 10,371.50 points. 
Front month Brent crude futures turned lower and were dropping 1.11% to $55.92 per barrel on the ICE, while cable surrendered 1.05% to 1.5443. 
Traders found few places to hide as gold futures were hit by strength in the US dollar, leaving sovereign bonds as one of the only havens available. 
Gold futures for August delivery were down 1.47% to $1,555.90 per ounce on COMEX. 
In parallel, the yield on the benchmark 10-year Gilt was down by 19 basis points to 1.82%. Yields on similarly dated US Treasury notes were eight basis points lower at 2.20%. 
Yields on Bunds were off by 13 basis points to 0.64% and those on 10-year Spanish government bonds by 10 basis points to 2.28%. 
Copper futures were to be seen 5.4% lower at $2.40 per pound on COMEX.
